Award.AwardTitle: A Comprehensive Approach to Interference Cancellation and Spurious Reduction in Broadband Wireless Transceivers

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Title:A Comprehensive Approach to Interference Cancellation and Spurious Reduction in Broadband Wireless Transceivers.
Institution: University of Texas at Austin.



This proposed effort will make significant contributions to wireless communication systems and will enhance access to the radio spectrum which has been identified as a national priority. If successful it will be transformative and will have major societal, commercial and economic benefits.The architectures and techniques researched here will find wide use in current and future radio technologies that enable broadband wireless access. Additionally, this research will impact multiple applications beyond communications, including safety, sensing, and medical devices. The investigators will collaborate closely amongst themselves, and with current industrial partners. Results of the research will be broadly disseminated through publications. Graduate students will be provided a cross-disciplinary learning experience that spans communication systems, architecture definition, integrated circuit design and measurement techniques. A strong educational program is a key aspect to ensuring the long-term dissemination of the proposed research results. As such, the principal investigators intend to integrate much of the aforementioned research into their regular course work. A diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged in this and related effort in the research teams.

Broadband wireless systems offer a viable approach for enabling ubiquitous high-speed communications. This effort will focus on key hardware challenges in the design of transceivers for such systems. Multiple questions will be addressed including: (a) the ability of the transmitter and the receiver to span a desired frequency range, with minimal hardware overhead and complexity, (b) the ability of the receiver to tolerate and operate satisfactorily in the presence of interference and (c) the ability of the transmitter to minimize its out-of-band spectral emissions, so as to minimize co-existence issues. This proposal seeks to address these considerations by developing a comprehensive approach for interference mitigation in broadband, rapidly tunable, integrated, wireless transceivers. The designs will be engineered to meet future high data-rate needs by enabling devices that allow for flexible, and reconfigurable use of spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broadband transceivers are essential to enabling wireless high data-rate communication systems. This effort has investigated several aspects of such transceivers, in the frequency-bands spanning the range in the range spanning tens of mega-hertz (MHz), to several giga-hertz (GHz).

 

The research, performed  at the University of Texas at Austin, and the University of Washington, Seattle,  has consisted of an investigation into two types of systems, a broadband receiver for GHz wide-signals, and a communication transceiver which allows for highly efficient usage of available spectrum by simultaneously using the same spectrum for transmission and reception.


A broadband receiver that employs a spectrum channelizer has been investigated. This approach allows for simultaneous downconversion of a very wide-spectrum analog signal, and converts it into the digital domain, where it is available for further signal processing. The approach can find application in software defined radios capable of dynamically employing spectrum for communications, as well as for broadband analog-to-digital conversion. A key challenge in such designs appears when one portion of the spectrum is large compared to others. This portion of the spectrum can then overwhelm the analog-to-digital converters in the design. A new approach for reducing the level of this large signal before the analog-to-digital converters has been shown in this effort. Another key design that has been undertaken relates to techniques for harmonic rejection downconversion mixers, which synthesize a local-oscillator signal, to allow for downconverting portions of the spectrum, with significantly reduced downconversion from harmonics of the local oscillator.

 

Spectrum is an increasingly precious resource for communications. As part of this research, advanced techniques for transceivers that can reuse spectrum for simultaneous transmission and reception, namely in-band full-duplex communications, have been demonstrated. Full-duplex systems can effectively double the spectrum available for communication. In such a transceiver, the output of the transmitter, which is operational concurrently with the receiver, can severely degrade the quality of signal reception, because the received signals are orders of magnitude smaller than the transmitted signals. An approach to prevent degradation of the received signal by canceling the transmitted signal in multiple points of the receiver chain has been demonstrated. The design has been practically demonstrated in an integrated circuit form to operate around 2 GHz, with nearly a million-fold reduction in the leakage signal, over the order of 50 MHz of signal bandwidth. This represents state-of-the-art cancellation for such applications. This research has also investigated harmonic-rejecting power amplifiers, wherein spurious emissions at harmonics of the transmitter local oscillator frequency are minimized, thus minimizing corruption for other users of the available spectrum. The techniques investigated here can beneficially impact a wide majority of current and emerging communication systems, relating to cellular and wifi systems.
